templateKey: content-pages
title: How does making choices help developing writers?
key: how-does-making-choices-help-developing-writers
parentKey: how-is-writing-a-social-activity
points:
  - point: >-
      Consider Katie in Chapter 4 and the distinctions she makes between writing
      a press release and the writing she was doing at school:


      <ExpandableBlockquote />
      previewText="%5Ba%5D%20press%20release%20is%20written%20like%20%u2026"
      fullText="%5B%5C%5Ba%5D%20press%20release%20is%20written%20like%20a%20newspaper%20article.%20You%20have%20to%20lead%20with%20the%20most%20important%20thing%2C%20and%20then%20you%20give%20the%20background%20information%20later%20on.%20Whereas%2C%20in%20college%20I%u2019d%20been%20writing%2C%20have%20the%20background%20information%20at%20the%20top%20and%20then%20get%20more%20and%20more%20specific%20or%20get%20to%20your%20point%20at%20the%20bottom%5D%28https%3A//hdl.handle.net/2027/fulcrum.10079890/poi.27%29"




      Katie understands the difference between writing a press release and an
      academic paper for class, listing the features of each.




      Author Ryan McCarty explains: 


      <ExpandableBlockquote />
      previewText="The%20emphasis%20on%20a%20broad%20collection%20of%20writing%20experiences%20..."
      fullText="%5BThe%20emphasis%20on%20a%20broad%20collection%20of%20writing%20experiences%20is%20noteworthy%2C%20illustrating%20that%2C%20for%20Katie%2C%20the%20writer%20she%20has%20become%20is%20one%20who%20can%20effectively%20distinguish%20between%20exigencies%20of%20particular%20contexts%2C%20drawing%20on%20the%20appropriate%20resources%20in%20her%20writing%20repertoire.%20%5D%28https%3A//hdl.handle.net/2027/fulcrum.10079890/poi.27%29"




      Rather than just writing the same way for different audiences, Katie
      identifies what the audience in each community needs and makes choices
      appropriately.




      Now consider Grace in Chapter 7:


      <ExpandableBlockquote />
      previewText="One%20of%20the%20reasons%20why%20I%20hate%20writing%20is%20because%20%u2026"
      fullText="%5BOne%20of%20the%20reasons%20why%20I%20hate%20writing%20is%20because%20I%u2019ll%20read%20%5C%5Bmy%20%20writing%5D%2C%20and%20I%u2019m%20%20like%2C%20%u2018This%20isn%u2019t%20just%20like%20these%20masterpieces%20from%20all%20these%20books%20that%20I%20read.%u2019%20Then%20I%20get%20really%20upset%20about%20it%2C%20because%20%u2026%20it%u2019s%20just%20a%20stylistic%20problem.%20It%20just%20doesn%u2019t%20flow%20the%20way%20I%20want%20it%20to.%20It%u2019s%20not%20perfect%2C%20and%20I%20think%20part%20of%20what%20makes%20me%20so%20frustrated%20about%20it%20is%20because%20I%20read%20these%20great%20books%20that%20I%u2019m%20never%20gonna%20match%20up%20to%20when%20I%20write.%20I%20just%20get%20really%20disheartened.%5D%28https%3A//hdl.handle.net/2027/fulcrum.10079890/poi.31%29"




      As author Anna Knutson explains, despite being an honors student and an
      avid reader, Grace hates writing because her school writing does not sound
      like the fiction she reads for fun. 




      Instead of making choices in her writing, like Katie, Grace attempts to
      write the same way regardless of audience their expectations: she doesn’t
      seem to recognize that the way something sounds in fiction won’t be the
      same way it sounds in other kinds of writing. Grace’s inability to
      recognize choices she can make in her writing prevents her from developing
      as a writer and makes her believe that she cannot write well.


      ## FOR INSTRUCTORS: helping students make choices


      Students benefit from being taught how to make choices in their writing to
      meet the needs and expectations of their audience. Take another look at
      Grace and how she’s been taught to write:


      <ExpandableBlockquote />
      previewText="Two%20years%20of%20AP%20English%20with%20the%20same%20instructor%20%u2026"
      fullText="%5BTwo%20years%20of%20AP%20English%20with%20the%20same%20instructor%20prepared%20her%20to%20succeed%20in%20at%20least%20two%20domains%20of%20writing%3A%20timed%20essay%20exams%2C%20such%20as%20the%20AP%20exam%20and%20the%20ACT%20exam%2C%20and%20his%20class%2C%20which%20seems%20to%20have%20had%20quite%20rigorous%u2014and%20specific%u2014standards%20for%20writing.%20Grace%20valued%20this%20learning%2C%20perhaps%20so%20much%20that%20it%20became%20entrenched%2C%20as%20Anson%20describes%3A%20%u2018When%20writers%u2019%20contexts%20are%20constrained%20and%20they%20are%20subjected%20to%20repeated%20practice%20of%20the%20%20same%20%20genres%2C%20%20using%20%20the%20%20same%20%20processes%20%20for%20%20the%20%20same%20%20rhetorical%20%20purposes%20%20and%20%20addressing%20the%20same%20audiences%2C%20their%20conceptual%20framework%20for%20writing%20may%20become%20entrenched%2C%20%u2018solidified%2C%u2019%20or%20%u2018sedimented%u2019%20%2877%29.%20Anson%20%20suggests%20%20that%20%20the%20%20%u201Cmisapplication%20%20of%20%20habituated%20%20practice%u201D%20%20is%20%20typical%20%20among%20high%20school%20students%20who%20have%20become%20accustomed%20to%20particular%20types%20of%20writing%3B%20Grace%20may%20be%20one%20of%20these%20students.%5D%28https%3A//hdl.handle.net/2027/fulcrum.10079890/poi.32%29"


      Practice in one type of writing can improve that one type, but it doesn’t
      help teach students how to make choices or develop flexibility in writing
      in different ways for different audiences. Check out [How writers respond
      to audience
      expectations](/pages/writing-is-social/how-is-writing-a-social-activity/how-do-writers-respond-to-audience-expectations/)
      for tips for teaching students to make choices in their writing that adapt
      to the varying needs of an audience.
    title: Having choices in writing
  - point: >-
      As author Naomi Silver explains, it’s about making choices, but it’s about
      reflecting on those choices. Naomi describes Sophie, who, in her entry
      interview, articulates why she chooses Prezi as her presentation medium:


      <ExpandableBlockquote />
      previewText="Prezi%20sort%20of%20allows%20you%20%u2026"
      fullText="%5BPrezi%20sort%20of%20allows%20you%20to%20almost%20communicate%20your%20thought%20process%20through%20the%20presentation%2C%20because%20you%20can%20zoom.%20We%20had%20this%20one%20map%20that%20we%u2019re%20showing%20and%20then%20we%20want%20to%20show%20another%20map%20next%20to%20it%20and%2C%20rather%20than%20clicking%20on%20the%20next%20slide%2C%20we%20just%20zoom%20out%2C%20and%20you%20can%20see%20both%20maps%20next%20to%20each%20other.%20Which%2C%20when%20you%u2019re%20watching%20something%2C%20it%u2019s%20just%20much%20more%20visually%20appealing.%5D%28https%3A//hdl.handle.net/2027/fulcrum.10079890/poi.33%29"


      Sophie describes a connection between what appears on two different maps
      and how she envisions their relationship


      <ExpandableBlockquote />
      previewText="by%20presenting%20the%20connection%20visually%20as%20well%20as%20verbally%20%u2026"
      fullText="%5Bby%20presenting%20the%20connection%20visually%20as%20well%20as%20verbally%20using%20the%20Prezi%20platform%u2019s%20unique%20%u2018zooming%u2019%20affordances%2C%20and%20she%20articulates%20that%20relationship%20in%20her%20depiction%20of%20the%20%u2018presentation%u2019%20itself%20as%20%u2018almost%20communicat%5C%5Bing%5D%20%5C%5Bher%5D%20thought%20process.%20Although%20Sophie%20falls%20back%20on%20the%20language%20of%20%u2018visual%20appeal%u2019%20%28similarly%20to%20Katie%29%20to%20explain%20why%20she%20prefers%20the%20spatial%20relationship%20enabled%20by%20the%20Prezi%20platform%20to%20a%20more%20linear%2C%20slide-based%20presentation%20platform%2C%20it%20seems%20clear%20that%20she%20has%20an%20intentional%20rhetorical%20design%20in%20mind%20%28metacognitive%20awareness%29%20and%20is%20able%20to%20choose%20the%20appropriate%20medium%20...%20to%20facilitate%20it%20%28metacognitive%20regulation%29.%5D%28https%3A//hdl.handle.net/2027/fulcrum.10079890/poi.33%29"


      Sophie makes a choice about why she uses prezi over powerpoint, and then
      can explain how prezi makes it the more effective presentation platform in
      this case.


      Jenna, also in Naomi’s chapter, explains how her writing choices help her
      develop her argument:


      <ExpandableBlockquote />
      previewText="I%20saw%20that%20there%20were%20a%20lot%20of%20different%20ways%20to%20say%20something%2C%20%u2026"
      fullText="%5BI%20saw%20that%20there%20were%20a%20lot%20of%20different%20ways%20to%20say%20something%2C%20if%20that%20makes%20sense.%20It%20depends%20who%20you%u2019re%20saying%20it%20to%20and%20why%20you%u2019re%20saying%20it.%20I%20realize%20you%20have%20to%20think%u2014there%20are%20a%20lot%20more%20decisions%20that%20go%20into%20how%20you%20want%20to%20convey%20something....Like%20how%20do%20you%20want%20to%u2014do%20you%20want%20it%20to%20be%20in%20an%20essay%3F%20Like%20literally%20words%20on%20a%20page%20or%20do%20you%20want%20to%20turn%20it%20into%20something%20with%20pictures%20or%20do%20you%20want%20to%20put%20it%20on%20a%20website%3F%20All%20of%20the%20things%20that%20play%20into%20that.%20If%20it%u2019s%20just%20an%20essay%20anyone%20can%20read%20it%20but%20then%20if%20you%20put%20pictures%20with%20it%20you%u2019re%20influencing%20people%20to%20see%20a%20certain%20thing%20or%20if%20you%20put%20it%20on%20a%20website%20then%20how%20do%20people%20navigate%20your%20website%20and%20where%20is%20the%20emphasis%3F%20There%u2019s%20so%20many%20decisions%20that%20go%20into%20that.%5D%28https%3A//hdl.handle.net/2027/fulcrum.10079890/poi.33%29"


      Jenna doesn’t make choices just because she knows she should, she reflects
      on which choices would be best to help develop and support her argument.


      ## FOR INSTRUCTORS: helping students reflect on the choices they make


      When students work on and submit writing assignments, consider having them
      submit a reflection that explains the variety of choices they made in
      their composition.


      Students can answer questions like, what audience are they writing to and
      what writing choices have they made to develop their argument for this
      audience? What kinds of expectations will their audience have about how
      their work is written? Will they be looking for particular formatting or
      organizational choices, for instance? What kind of evidence would appeal
      to this audience?


      These conversations can occur at any stage of the writing process.
    title: 'Making choices, reflecting on them, and developing as a writer'
  - point: >-
      Students considered themselves writers when they could draw on their range
      of writing resources, make decisions about which resources to use, and
      reflect on those choices. Author Anne Gere highlights students who talk
      about this process:


      <ExpandableBlockquote />
      previewText="For%20example%2C%20in%20talking%20about%20a%20writing%20course%2C%20Joy%20commented%20on%20learning%20%u2026"
      fullText="%5BFor%20example%2C%20in%20talking%20about%20a%20writing%20course%2C%20Joy%20commented%20on%20learning%20about%20the%20ethics%20in%20writing%20and%20how%20to%20be%20a%20more%20credible%20writer.%20Those%20are%20skills%20that%20I%20can%20carry%20over%20to%20magazine%20journalism....I%20would%20definitely%20take%20what%20I%u2019ve%20learned%20%20in%20%20this%20%20class%20%20and%20%20apply%20%20it%20%20to%20%20making%20%20videos%20%20for%20%u2018Her%20%20Campus%2C%u2019%20%20a%20%20nationally%20circulated%20online%20magazine.%20Sophia%20talked%20about%20using%20reflection%20outside%20of%20the%20academy%3A%20%u2018I%20had%20to%20apply%2C%20over%20the%20summer%2C%20for%20that%20job.%20It%20was%20a%20lot%20about%20reflecting%20on%20past%20experiences%20in%20terms%20of%20leadership%2C%20and%20working%20in%20teams%20and%20stuff%20like%20that.%20That%20kind%20of%20forced%20me%20to%20think%20about%20all%20the%20experience%20I%u2019d%20had%20up%20until%20that%20point%20and%20flesh%20them%20out%20into%20a%20way%20that%20made%20me%20seem%20desirable%20as%20a%20candidate.%u2019%20Because%20she%20had%20learned%20how%20to%20reflect%20on%20her%20writing%2C%20Sophie%20was%20able%20to%20transfer%20that%20capacity%20%20to%20%20writing%20%20a%20%20job%20%20application.%20%20In%20%20addition%20%20to%20%20transferring%20%20learning%20%20from%20%20one%20context%20to%20another%2C%20the%20repertoires%20students%20claimed%20gave%20them%20rhetorical%20flexibility%3A%20%u2018My%20style%20changes%20based%20off%20of%20what%20type%20of%20paper%20it%20is%2C%u2019%20said%20Jack.%20Jonah%20claimed%2C%20%u2018I%20think%20that%20%5C%5Breflection%5D%20eventually%20will%20translate%20into%2C%20will%20help%20me%20in%20a%20job%20in%20the%20future%2C%20just%20being%20able%20to%20adapt%20and%20learn%20different%20ways%20of%20writing....I%u2019m%20probably%20not%20%20going%20%20to%20%20be%20%20writing%20%20research%20%20papers%20%20or%20%20essays%20%20about%20%20stuff%2C%20%20but%20%20I%20%20think%20%20it%20%20does%20translate%20into%20other%20ways%20of%20working.%u2019%20This%20capacity%20for%20using%20reflection%20to%20identify%20one%u2019s%20%20own%20%20writerly%20%20abilities%20%20and%20%20to%20figure%20%20out%20%20how%20%20to%20%20use%20%20them%20%20in%20%20new%20%20situations%20points%20to%20another%20dimension%20of%20writing%20development.%5D%28https%3A//hdl.handle.net/2027/fulcrum.10079890/poi.36%29"


      This is similar to students’ reflections about making multimodal choices
      and becoming a “writer”: [How do writers compose in the digital
      age?](/pages/writing-involves-choices/how-do-we-write-in-the-digital-age/how-do-writers-compose-in-the-digital-age/#writing-multimodally-and-becoming-“a-writer)
    title: 'Making choices, reflecting, and becoming a “writer”'
afterPoints: >-
  When writers are given the opportunity to make their own choices to fit the
  needs of their audience, they are more likely to consider themselves writers.
---
In our study, we learned that when writers can make their own choices to fit the needs of their audience and the expectations of that community, they are more likely to consider themselves effective writers.

<ExpandableBlockquote previewText="Prezi%20sort%20of%20allows%20you%20%u2026" fullText="%5BPrezi%20sort%20of%20allows%20you%20to%20almost%20communicate%20your%20thought%20process%20through%20the%20presentation%2C%20because%20you%20can%20zoom.%20We%20had%20this%20one%20map%20that%20we%u2019re%20showing%20and%20then%20we%20want%20to%20show%20another%20map%20next%20to%20it%20and%2C%20rather%20than%20clicking%20on%20the%20next%20slide%2C%20we%20just%20zoom%20out%2C%20and%20you%20can%20see%20both%20maps%20next%20to%20each%20other.%20Which%2C%20when%20you%u2019re%20watching%20something%2C%20it%u2019s%20just%20much%20more%20visually%20appealing.%5D%28https%3A//hdl.handle.net/2027/fulcrum.10079890/poi.33%29" />

Sophie describes a connection between what appears on two different maps and how she envisions their relationship

<ExpandableBlockquote previewText="by%20presenting%20the%20connection%20visually%20as%20well%20as%20verbally%20%u2026" fullText="%5Bby%20presenting%20the%20connection%20visually%20as%20well%20as%20verbally%20using%20the%20Prezi%20platform%u2019s%20unique%20%u2018zooming%u2019%20affordances%2C%20and%20she%20articulates%20that%20relationship%20in%20her%20depiction%20of%20the%20%u2018presentation%u2019%20itself%20as%20%u2018almost%20communicat%5C%5Bing%5D%20%5C%5Bher%5D%20thought%20process.%20Although%20Sophie%20falls%20back%20on%20the%20language%20of%20%u2018visual%20appeal%u2019%20%28similarly%20to%20Katie%29%20to%20explain%20why%20she%20prefers%20the%20spatial%20relationship%20enabled%20by%20the%20Prezi%20platform%20to%20a%20more%20linear%2C%20slide-based%20presentation%20platform%2C%20it%20seems%20clear%20that%20she%20has%20an%20intentional%20rhetorical%20design%20in%20mind%20%28metacognitive%20awareness%29%20and%20is%20able%20to%20choose%20the%20appropriate%20medium%20...%20to%20facilitate%20it%20%28metacognitive%20regulation%29.%5D%28https%3A//hdl.handle.net/2027/fulcrum.10079890/poi.33%29" />

Sophie makes a choice about why she uses prezi over powerpoint, and then can explain how prezi makes it the more effective presentation platform in this case.

Jenna, also in Naomi’s chapter, explains how her writing choices help her develop her argument:

<ExpandableBlockquote previewText="I%20saw%20that%20there%20were%20a%20lot%20of%20different%20ways%20to%20say%20something%2C%20%u2026" fullText="%5BI%20saw%20that%20there%20were%20a%20lot%20of%20different%20ways%20to%20say%20something%2C%20if%20that%20makes%20sense.%20It%20depends%20who%20you%u2019re%20saying%20it%20to%20and%20why%20you%u2019re%20saying%20it.%20I%20realize%20you%20have%20to%20think%u2014there%20are%20a%20lot%20more%20decisions%20that%20go%20into%20how%20you%20want%20to%20convey%20something....Like%20how%20do%20you%20want%20to%u2014do%20you%20want%20it%20to%20be%20in%20an%20essay%3F%20Like%20literally%20words%20on%20a%20page%20or%20do%20you%20want%20to%20turn%20it%20into%20something%20with%20pictures%20or%20do%20you%20want%20to%20put%20it%20on%20a%20website%3F%20All%20of%20the%20things%20that%20play%20into%20that.%20If%20it%u2019s%20just%20an%20essay%20anyone%20can%20read%20it%20but%20then%20if%20you%20put%20pictures%20with%20it%20you%u2019re%20influencing%20people%20to%20see%20a%20certain%20thing%20or%20if%20you%20put%20it%20on%20a%20website%20then%20how%20do%20people%20navigate%20your%20website%20and%20where%20is%20the%20emphasis%3F%20There%u2019s%20so%20many%20decisions%20that%20go%20into%20that.%5D%28https%3A//hdl.handle.net/2027/fulcrum.10079890/poi.33%29" />

Jenna doesn’t make choices just because she knows she should, she reflects on which choices would be best to help develop and support her argument.

## FOR INSTRUCTORS: helping students reflect on the choices they make

When students work on and submit writing assignments, consider having them submit a reflection that explains the variety of choices they made in their composition.

Students can answer questions like, what audience are they writing to and what writing choices have they made to develop their argument for this audience? What kinds of expectations will their audience have about how their work is written? Will they be looking for particular formatting or organizational choices, for instance? What kind of evidence would appeal to this audience?

These conversations can occur at any stage of the writing process.
points.title: Making choices, reflecting on them, and developing as a writer

points.point:
Students considered themselves writers when they could draw on their range of writing resources, make decisions about which resources to use, and reflect on those choices. Author Anne Gere highlights students who talk about this process:

<ExpandableBlockquote previewText="For%20example%2C%20in%20talking%20about%20a%20writing%20course%2C%20Joy%20commented%20on%20learning%20%u2026" fullText="%5BFor%20example%2C%20in%20talking%20about%20a%20writing%20course%2C%20Joy%20commented%20on%20learning%20about%20the%20ethics%20in%20writing%20and%20how%20to%20be%20a%20more%20credible%20writer.%20Those%20are%20skills%20that%20I%20can%20carry%20over%20to%20magazine%20journalism....I%20would%20definitely%20take%20what%20I%u2019ve%20learned%20%20in%20%20this%20%20class%20%20and%20%20apply%20%20it%20%20to%20%20making%20%20videos%20%20for%20%u2018Her%20%20Campus%2C%u2019%20%20a%20%20nationally%20circulated%20online%20magazine.%20Sophia%20talked%20about%20using%20reflection%20outside%20of%20the%20academy%3A%20%u2018I%20had%20to%20apply%2C%20over%20the%20summer%2C%20for%20that%20job.%20It%20was%20a%20lot%20about%20reflecting%20on%20past%20experiences%20in%20terms%20of%20leadership%2C%20and%20working%20in%20teams%20and%20stuff%20like%20that.%20That%20kind%20of%20forced%20me%20to%20think%20about%20all%20the%20experience%20I%u2019d%20had%20up%20until%20that%20point%20and%20flesh%20them%20out%20into%20a%20way%20that%20made%20me%20seem%20desirable%20as%20a%20candidate.%u2019%20Because%20she%20had%20learned%20how%20to%20reflect%20on%20her%20writing%2C%20Sophie%20was%20able%20to%20transfer%20that%20capacity%20%20to%20%20writing%20%20a%20%20job%20%20application.%20%20In%20%20addition%20%20to%20%20transferring%20%20learning%20%20from%20%20one%20context%20to%20another%2C%20the%20repertoires%20students%20claimed%20gave%20them%20rhetorical%20flexibility%3A%20%u2018My%20style%20changes%20based%20off%20of%20what%20type%20of%20paper%20it%20is%2C%u2019%20said%20Jack.%20Jonah%20claimed%2C%20%u2018I%20think%20that%20%5C%5Breflection%5D%20eventually%20will%20translate%20into%2C%20will%20help%20me%20in%20a%20job%20in%20the%20future%2C%20just%20being%20able%20to%20adapt%20and%20learn%20different%20ways%20of%20writing....I%u2019m%20probably%20not%20%20going%20%20to%20%20be%20%20writing%20%20research%20%20papers%20%20or%20%20essays%20%20about%20%20stuff%2C%20%20but%20%20I%20%20think%20%20it%20%20does%20translate%20into%20other%20ways%20of%20working.%u2019%20This%20capacity%20for%20using%20reflection%20to%20identify%20one%u2019s%20%20own%20%20writerly%20%20abilities%20%20and%20%20to%20figure%20%20out%20%20how%20%20to%20%20use%20%20them%20%20in%20%20new%20%20situations%20points%20to%20another%20dimension%20of%20writing%20development.%5D%28https%3A//hdl.handle.net/2027/fulcrum.10079890/poi.36%29" />

This is similar to students’ reflections about making multimodal choices and becoming a “writer”: [How do writers compose in the digital age?](/pages/writing-involves-choices/how-do-we-write-in-the-digital-age/how-do-writers-compose-in-the-digital-age/#writing-multimodally-and-becoming-“a-writer)
